A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.

A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
A field is a commutative division ring.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the intersection $\mathfrak{a} \cap \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{x ; x \in \mathfrak{a} \text { and } x \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The image of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{im} \varphi$, is defined as $\varphi(R)$, which is a subring of $R'$.
The canonical homomorphism $\\[Phi: R[X] \\longrightarrow R /(p)[X]\\]$ is a ring homomorphism that reduces the coefficients of a polynomial modulo a prime element $p$ in $R$.
The torsion submodule T of an A-module M consists of all torsion elements of M. If T = 0, M is called torsion-free; if T = M, it is called a torsion module.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is integral if every element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ in the way described in the definition of an integral element over a ring.

An extension field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q / \mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field consisting of $q=p^n$ elements, where $p$ is a prime number and $n$ is a positive integer. This field is uniquely characterized up to isomorphism as a splitting field of the polynomial $X^q-X$ over $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$.
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The stabilizer or isotropy subgroup of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G_{x}:=\{g \in G ; g x=x\}$.

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
The kernel of \( f \) is defined as:\[\mathrm{Ker}(f) = \{ a \in A \mid f(a) = 0 \} and is hence a subset of the Domain A.\]

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of a ring includes the requirement for two laws of composition (addition and multiplication), thus it depends on the concept of a law of composition.
The definition of a field as a commutative division ring implies that it is a special type of ring, thus its definition depends on the concept of a ring.
The intersection of ideals is specifically defined within the context of a ring, thus its definition depends on the concept of a ring.
The image of a ring homomorphism is defined within the context of ring homomorphisms, which inherently depends on the concept of a ring.
The canonical homomorphism is a type of ring homomorphism, which inherently depends on the concept of a ring.
The integral ring homomorphism is a type of ring homomorphism, which inherently depends on the concept of a ring.
An extension field is defined as a type of field, thus its definition depends on the concept of a field.
